citations.narrative:
Two primary enclosures housing one kinkajou each per enclosure were found to have areas of vinyl flooring that had
been torn away from the wooden floor underneath. These damaged areas of flooring present a risk of ingestion by the
animals. The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to
protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals. Correct by August 8, 2024.

The primary enclosure housing the coati was measured to be 29 inches away from the perimeter fence. Insufficient
distance between the primary enclosure and perimeter fence may allow unwanted contact between animals inside the
enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence. Such fences less than three feet in distance from the
primary enclosure must be approved in writing by the Administrator. Correct by seeking approval from the Administrator or
moving the enclosure at least three feet away from the perimeter fence. Correct by August 8, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
David Mersereau, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Marla Renshaw, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Two primary enclosures housing one kinkajou each per enclosure were found to have areas of vinyl flooring that had 
been torn away from the wooden floor underneath. These damaged areas of flooring present a risk of ingestion by the 
animals. The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to 
protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals. Correct by August 8, 2024. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The primary enclosure housing the coati was measured to be 29 inches away from the perimeter fence. Insufficient 
distance between the primary enclosure and perimeter fence may allow unwanted contact between animals inside the 
enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence. Such fences less than three feet in distance from the 
primary enclosure must be approved in writing by the Administrator. Correct by seeking approval from the Administrator or 
moving the enclosure at least three feet away from the perimeter fence. Correct by August 8, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
David Mersereau, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
Marla Renshaw, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
